correspAction.name: [the North-Eastern and Goulburn Valley Agricultural and Pastoral Association]

head.supplied: [Our Tatura ¶ Vic. ¶ correspondent reports:— "Samples of a thistle apparently new to this district were forwarded by the secretary of the North-Eastern and Goulburn Valley Agricultural and Pastoral A...

div.p: To [the North-Eastern and Goulburn Valley Agricultural and Pastoral Association]

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Letter not found. The text given here is from 'Country news', Argus, 19 May 1887, p. 7.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

p.seg: correspondent reports:— "Samples of a thistle apparently new to this district were forwarded by the secretary of the North-Eastern and Goulburn Valley Agricultural and Pastoral Association on the 4th inst. to the secretary for agriculture, and by him transmitted to the Government botanist,

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

p.seg: who reports that the thistle is botanically known as 'Centawnea cateitrupa,'

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

p.seg: and in Britain it is commonly called 'star thistle.' It extends from the south of England to the countries on the Mediterranean Sea and to North-Western India. It can be prevented from spreading by cutting and burning the plants before seeding.]
